paragraph.value: Table 3 compares the performance of the four weighting variants introduced in Section 3.2.
, which sums the transformed representations and then weights each component of the summed representation, has the weakest performance, with only
of the test compounds receiving a rank that is lower than 5. A
– is obtained by applying the same weighting for each column of the transformations matrix H. The results of
are interesting in two respects: first, it outperforms the feature variation,
, despite training a smaller number of parameters (
in our setup). Second, it performs on par with the
variation, although the latter has a larger number of parameters (
in our setup). This suggests that an effective combination method needs to take into account full transformations, i.e. entire rows of H and combine them in a systematic way.

builds on this insight by making each element of the final composed representation p dependent on each component of the transformed representation H. The result is a noteworthy increase in the quality of the predictions, with
more of the test representations having a rank ≤5. Although this weighting does use significantly more parameters than the previous weightings (

parameters), the number of parameters is relative to the number of transformations t and does not grow with the size of the vocabulary. As the results in the next subsection show, a relatively small number of transformations is sufficient even for larger training vocabularies.
